reviewText:
We have an expression in Australia that means the same thing as the ‘F’ word. It’s called to root. Therefore to have been f***ed is to have been rooted. After playing Rooted Concepts’ Bonsai for  a short period of time (an entire 82 minutes) that’s exactly how I and my poor computer (which was an upper echelon computer when purchased new back in July) feel. The game is a complete resource hog for absolutely no excusable reason and what is present isn’t much of a game whatsoever. This, my dear readers, makes Bonsai the plant version of the infamous Bad Rats and a game that will be given as a prank gift for years to come.

It’s as much a game as watching grass growing is a spectator sport. Seriously. In order for your plant to grow you wait extended periods of time – you’re best alt-tabbing out during that time and doing something else – and then when it’s grown enough you can then snip the parts that you don’t want. But it’s the waiting that is annoying and the fact that every time it grows it takes up yet more resources. If your tree grows enough the amount of resources that are consumed becomes ridiculous and will slow your game down to a grinding halt. It’s a very bizarre combination of poor design and programming choices.

If I were to find two things that are redeeming and positive about the game then the first are the cheap achievements. Start a new game and if you get a type of plant that you haven’t grown before you receive an achievement. The other is that the game does have the potential to be a soothing experience. That is if you have China’s supercomputer to run the program on due to the game being a resource hog.

Unfortunately, I cannot recommend Bonsai to anyone due to the problems with the programming. It’s just a poorly programmed and designed game that shouldn’t have been released in its current state. Had the title been released in the Early Access programs the issues may have been overlooked because it is clear that they need a lot of work and that’s what that program in part signifies. However, it’s not and I can’t see the problems with the coding or the design choices changing nearly as much as is necessary for the game to reach recommended status.

For similar reviews and our popular daily giveaways visit http://www.steamified.com/
For our Steam group and Curation please join http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Steamified

reviewText: Pruning down trees without philosophy"Bonsai is a simple tree growing and pruning branches simulator. Like Viridi it's also a longtime investing idle game with not many options. But what does it have to do with bonsai? AFAIK no Bonsai master has ever used a chainsaw to prune armthick branches. This unrealistic game works like growing your tree to the max with intense watering and then prune endlessy regrowing branches. After 100 GCs the stem and branches got thicker than you can cut off with any scissors. So to speak a logical disappointment. Though the fractal branch generation and the typical tree characteristics look quite neat you wonder why this game is not educating you more about the Japanese philosophy. What about perfection through reduction? Cutting down growlings and leaves to force a tree into a bonsai shape. It could be more fascinating to generate miniature trees than normal trees. And to cutoff 6k branches as a master goal wouldn't be neccessary anymore. Pity what a missed chance ..."

reviewText:
Apparently I'm in the minority by saying that I honestly enjoyed this game. Bonsai, contrary to what many people think, is the Japanese art form of cultivating and pruning miniature trees grown within small containers; it is NOT a specific type of tree. And this game is exactly that.

You start out with a tiny sapling on a square of grass, and either a day or night sky background depending on the time you play. You can water your sapling to speed up its growth and it will steadily grow into one of five types of tree: each with its own species appropriate bark, leaf shapes, and leaf colour. As it grows branches and twigs, you use the scissors to trim it into whatever shapes you wish. Trimming and shaping the tree's growth is supposed to be calming and contemplative. I found it to be rather relaxing.

Having said all of this, there are certain things this game could improve upon:
The soundtrackIs unfortunately out of place. With a game focused on relaxation, I was expecting its music to be more reiki. It instead seemed to fit more for a childish platformer. Turn it off to enjoy.
The leaves
Currently you can only trim branches, and the leaves that generate around the branches and twigs have white outlines on some of them. Hopefully in time you'll be able to shape the leaves to your liking, and they'll improve their graphics.
The base
As it is, the base of the tree is merely a square of grass. An assortment of containers and pots to choose from to fit your tree would be far better.
The trees themselves
More species, especially those that are more commonly found in the art of Bonsai would definitely improve this game.

If you just want a simple, relaxing game to play while you think about things, pick this up, turn off the sound, and play some gentle music to trim your tree to. Otherwise, avoid Bonsai: it's not something for those who want a real game"."

reviewText:
I am really enjoying this game, it is extremely intense growing your tree trying to beat all the other players trees and ultimatly growing yours to the greatest heights that you can reach.

The multiplayer elements are brilliantly implemented while keeping them seperate with an option to disable them.

The graphics are beatiful and remind me of the Nimmy Neutron games on the Gamecube.

It can be a very relaxed game at times and is a good way to get away from everyhting.

10/10

reviewText:
This game is bad. Trees don't grow like this. I played for about 15 minutes, my tree grew to have a couple of branches, but it never had any leaves. It just looked like firewood sticking up from the ground. Trees don't grow without foliage!

The definition of a bonsai is tree in a pot". This game doesn't have pots. The tree just grows in a rectangular slab with some green on top.

The game allows for some realistic bonsai development in the sense that you can let the tree grow taller and then chop it down to get low branching. But the branches that appear from the chop point are immediately far too thick
date: almost the thickness of the stem below the cut point! That's not how it works! You can't build taper into your tree this way. Even the sample trees on the Steam images and videos look very young and slender. Bonsai trees are supposed to look old
